I am not calling it a phase because I decry communism and anarchism of any historical or political meaning —I myself align myself to mutualism in a philosophical level.

I am calling it a phase because most young commies are still in the early stages of adulthood. What this means is that a lot of their chosen ideology comes from what usually comes with growing up: rebelling against preconceived social norms, finding the idea of having no certain future disconcerting, feeling disenfranchised from the status quo and its political shapes, trying to find a place or a community in the world, etc. that's why commies and ancoms on social media bind primarily over aesthetics (the typical punkish ancom or the wannabe militant MLM) instead of well-thought beliefs. that's why edginess becomes such a big part of their behavior (defending some random dictator, talking about "the revolution", emphasizing vague notions of "direct action", etc.). They behave as social cliques and groups more than actual movements, especially in the current modern society where incentives are waaaay different from the 1920s where unions actually had some leverage. Silly me forgot to bump the thread Edition
previous: >>29519352

Goal of the thread: At the end of the day, try to write a journal entry listing positive experiences you had throughout the day, cute things you've seen, things that were nice, you get the idea.
Daily goals can be repeated. Remember to keep score, it can only go up!

>What is this thread for?
Getting better is hard, and sucks. A lot. It does not get easier doing it alone.
Share resources and experiences with combating depression, anxiety, personal issues, achieving or maintaining a healthy weight, etc.
>Why is this thread /lgbt/?
Struggles with mental and physical health are an indisputable part of /lgbt/ life, be it from dysphoria, social pressure, heartbreak, or just unfortunate lifestyle choices.
>Notes to consider:
Please be civil. Shame is your greatest enemy in fighting urges of self abuse (be it sh, drugs, or just self deprecation). Relapsing into bad and unhealthy habits is to be expected, the goal is to increase the average amount of time it takes between relapses. Any improvement is a victory no matter how small. Your worth and right to get better are non-negotiable. And most importantly:
WE ARE NOT THERAPISTS, WE DON'T REPLACE MEDICATION
>Note on advice
Generic advice won't necessarily help you in particular, but for those it does it is an essential foundation to build future progress on, not a miracle cure. Do not underestimate the effects subtle changes to your lifestyle can have. Try first, keep us posted on your progress, build from there.

We are *always* short on self help resources, so if anything was useful to you, let us know!
Since the OP is getting too long I moved all resources into their own post, see below!

resources:
Exercise, diet, weight loss/gain: >>>/fit/17018018 (sticky)

ED: https://www.eatingdisorderhope.com/treatment-for-eating-disorders

General advice from Anons: https://0x0.st/oh5x.txt

Get started with weight loss (courtesy of /fit/fat/):
>What do I do first?
1. Read https://physiqonomics.com/fat-loss/
2. Calculate your Body Fat Percentage: https://fitness.bizcalcs.com/Calculator.asp?Calc=Body-Fat-Navy
3. Calculate your TDEE: https://www.sailrabbit.com/bmr/
Remember to use bodyfat% and use Katch-McArdle Formula with sedentary settings or your TDEE will be too high.
4. Plan your weight loss: https://www.losertown.org/eats/cal.php
5. Track your nutrition with LoseIt, Cronometer or Waistline (Open Source)

I don't know if there's an undergrad functional analysis (and would probably not count) but, this is what would be needed here.

>single+mutli-variable calculus
>linear algebra
>differential equations
>real analysis
>measure theory
>functional analysis

If you study full time, then technically you can make it in a year, but functional analysis is at least mid level or upper level of grad level courses, since it has grad level course as a pre-requisite.
I think you also want

>linear+non-linear optimization
>topology
>differential geometry

That's my goal at least, but I don't intend to work in ML (probably only try to do youtubes), since I'd need to get minimum masters, but probably a PhD (and then move to US to actually make any significant amount of money).
Maybe throw in probability theory there too, but you can cover that when you do measure theory afaik.

Also, PhD students start failing at measure theory, though usually because they "try too hard" to write their own proofs.
That level starts requiring a lot of work, it's not something you can do on the side of work (you can, but it'll take a while).

You can try walking them through some basic thought inspection. E.g. ask them questions such as
>Do I know for a fact that the worst case scenario will happen?

>What are some other possible outcomes, either neutral or positive? Is it really so unlikely that none of them will occur?

>while I could more or less get the gist of it, I couldn't even begin to solve it.
so the constraint is x^2 + y^2 + z^2 = 27
and you want to optimize F = x^3 + y^3 + z^3
you can use that to define z^2 = 27 - (x^2 + y^2), which also implies z^3 = (27 - (x^2 + y^2))^3/2
then you take the partial derivatives to find the critical points and check boundary
it's a pain

By intuition, they're minimizing the margin and minimizing the error, I think.
So my initial thoughts are, and also the ones I'm sticking to.
Since every sample is exclusive to several dimensions there's just not many ways to draw a plane that goes as close to each one of them.
So then it might just be a property of distributions, at some dimensions:samples ratio the chances of dimension exclusivity increases.

It's a phenomenon, so it's not entirely useless... But it's of no use right now, since it has no practical application (and I can't imagine an application for it, but then again I'm a John Snow who knows nothing).

It feels like unpassing MtFs get treated like shit way more than unpassing FtMs, but when an MtF passes, it is more likely that people consider her a woman than for people consider passing FtMs as men.

Speculatively, it feels like standards for femininity and "female behaviour" have loosened a lot in the past few decades. Not entirely of course, but there are looser and lower standards to what is considered womanly behaviours, than the standards for manly behaviours. As long as an MtF physically passes and behaviourally isn't way too autistic, she's just "the nerdy girl" to cis women. For cis straight men, they just want to fuck, so if she passes, these men are practically incentivised to think of her as a woman.

Meanwhile, for passing FtMs, it seems harder to break that perception of "butch lesbian who looks like a man". There are still strict codes and boundaries around what is manly enough, in terms of thoughts and behaviours. And no significant demographic has enough hornybrain for passing FtMs to bias their judgment towards seeing FtMs as men.

The whole "MtFs are women, FtMs are women" thing sums it up perfect. From a cis male perspective, they are straight so if they are sexually attracted to an MtF, then she is a woman. But the strict requirements of masculinity are what they judge FtMs by, hornybrain doesn't factor into that after all.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>29637624

Yeah I'm enby and I feel this. For me personally, I have pretty bad dysphoria about my masculine features. Just to get closer to a comfy androgynous point I basically need to do a whole MTF transition: I'm on full-blown HRT, I got a hair transplant recently, I'm doing electrolysis, voice training, learning makeup, etc., so I feel pretty comfortable ID-ing as trans, bc my experiences and healthcare needs overlap with many other trans people. I'm just not a binary trans person, nor do I need to pass as anything to get relief from dysphoria (which is all I really want, idc if someone sees me socially as enby or man or woman or whatever). So my experiences are different, too, and I understand it's not my place to speak beyond my own knowledge and experience.

That being said, there are some enbies who only have "social dysphoria" and don't really see the need to make any presentational or physical alterations so long as they don't have to socially exist as their AGAB all the time. I don't really understand their experiences, but I'm 100% onboard with them claiming non-binary if that's what makes them happy. I just cringe when I see non-transitioning enbies inserting themselves into trans discourse etc.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>29538164
likely because it's currently a very new, cutting-edge, experimental addition to the mtf transition regimen and isn't yet part of mainstream hrt prescription in any country.
pio itself though is well-tested amusingly has a better safety profile than almost any hrt medication currently prescribed in mainstream health, with physically-feminizing results that outpace basically anything except estradiol itself, and often outpacing even that.
the only worries have been a theorized small risk of bladder cancer, which recent studies have since debunked, and that it may possibly stunt breast growth, which - while still yet undetermined - anecdotally does not appear to be the case in the experiences documented in the pio thread we just had:
https://archived.moe/lgbt/thread/29496633
any experiences and ongoing results with as much detail as you can provide are, of course, always appreciated in this thread

>>29538640
Pioglitazone does not lower blood sugar levels directly.

It increases tissue insulin sensitivity, which is generally a positive effect in anyone. It's also used to improve diastolic blood pressure in non-diabetics.

As there's no sign of caloric loss or gain on pioglitazone in study participants it's safe to say that it's not driving people's blood sugar down.

from the will powers reddit:
>When people lack enough fat cells to store excess energy, there is nowhere for the energy to go. So the sugar and triglycerides just circulate, like a car trying to find a free parking spot in a packed carpark. Pio adds more free parking spots.
>Your blood glucose will not lower more than normal. It only lowers blood glucose for people who already had abnormally high blood glucose levels prior.
>Pioglitazone's mechanism is to bias stem cells towards producing fat cells more than they usually would. Potential side effect could be a very gradual reduction in muscle and bone mass over time, so it is recommended to cycle it on and off, or take a lower dose. These problems are hypothetical and have not been observed in healthy trans people in practice.

>>29539422
standard dose of pioglitazone is 30mg per day, not to exceed 45mg.
some trans girls do 15mg a day when cutting (to save money/wear and tear on the body) and 30mg a day when gaining. that's up to you.
you also ideally want to gain as fast as possible when in a gain cycle on pio since rapid gain makes your body prefer to make new fat cells (placed in feminine spots with proper female estrogen/testosterone level + the pio) instead of filling old ones (where your male fat cells already exist).
try to stick to healthy, good fats when you do this. trans fats lead directly to visceral fat (which is going to encourage male fat patterning if you're struggling with that). alcohol is bad for this too.
pioglitazone is still the wild west as far as the most effective doses/methods/timing goes for feminization, so ymmv, do your research, etc.
but the standard for virtually guaranteed results either way seems to be 30mg a day.

solely estrogen-based fat "redistribution" takes like an actual decade to complete with perfect levels.
fat cells are extremely slow to respond to endocrine movement: every year, whether you're fat or thin, whether you lose weight or gain, about 10 percent of your fat cells die and get replaced according to your hormonal patterns.
the progress in body feminization made once introducing pio does not appear to be consistent with an overall transition timeline.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Evidence that rosiglitazone, a similar drug from the family of glitazones, improves subcutaneous fat deposition beyond lower body (including face)
source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2895409/
It's likely that due to pio's similarity, it has the same effect.

Thread in a "women-only" sureddit about aesthetic self improvement, with anecdotal evidence that pioglitazone has improved their fat distribution:
>"Right, there's only 1 study about thiazolidinedione showing it can manipulate subcut fat, and it was done on a specific subpopulation (mtf trans) and in specific conditions (already had hrt, wanted to increase redistribution)
>but I given the other things I knew ab, I decided the parts we knew kinda fitted well enough together to be worth trying, so I've been playing with oral pioglitazone, and desu the result are nothing short of amazing."
>and the few ppl also using it (including 1 who just had preexisting diabetis then transitioned) reported results that are wayyy outside the normal. hopefully we'll have more research on that.
(this refers to that study we already know here)
>I had some facial fat loss maybe due to the various weird stuff I tried (not just tretinoin lol) + a very intense diet that left me with chicken wings, but at 6 month of pio I've regained everything in the face - and some more! and it's had a great effect on hips/butt which was my #1 failo before, even after a fat transfer..."
Again, this is anecdotal evidence that pio has at redistribution effects beyond the usually-studied abdominal and femoral VAT and SAT, including the face subcutaneous fat. Subject is a trans woman that reports not having had androgens for 6 years.
source: https://www.reddit.com/r/Vindicta/comments/txxv5x/comment/i3rrt1q/?utm_source=reddit&utm_medium=web2x&context=3

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>29548306
Not pio-related but here is anecdotal evidence that E2 gel improved facial distribution on a 35 year old PCOS woman
>"Estrogen has done for my face what no peels, fillers, treatments were ever able to do. I have spent thousands of dollars on skin care like laprairie and it doesn’t compare. Estrogen has thickened my skin and restores volume in my cheeks. My under eye has filled up. My lips too ( ok not like fillers but they stay hydrated and look better). The tone is the most important change. It just looks fresh and plump and rosier.
source: https://old.reddit.com/r/estrogel/comments/tpzz97/review_of_topical_estrogens_for_facial_effects/i3ovhs1/

Rosiglitazone has a lipogenic effect on facial subcutaneous depots.
>"Subcutaneous preadipocytes were isolated from human facial and abdominal skin and cultured in the presence of differentiation factors including rosiglitazone [...] Unexpected superior adipogenic capacity of facial preadipocytes was observed; more facial preadipocytes differentiated in response to rosiglitazone than abdominal preadipocytes and facial preadipocytes retained their ability to differentiate"
source: https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.4161/21623945.2014.955402

However, glitazones, as ligands of the PPARgamma receptors, may have a negative impact on breast growth. Some studies report breast cancer growth inhibition when glitazones like pioglitazone and rosiglitazone are used and activate PPARgamma:
>"Ligands for PPARγ include natural compounds such as fatty acids and their derivatives and synthetic agents such as the antidiabetic drugs rosiglitazone (Avandia) and pioglitazone (Actos) [13]. Although central role of PPAR-γ has been demonstrated in the differentiation of adipose cells, PPARγ has also been shown to regulate the growth, differentiation, and gene expression in number of different cancer cells"
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2676298/

>>29578108
Example would be
>totally identical estrogen/progesterone etc dosing throughout entire trial
>reasonably consistent diet and exercise throughout (whether that's shit diet and no exercise or healthy and exercise, doesn't matter but noting what it was is good info)
>start at weight x, take extensive measurements
>change weight by y over time period t, take extensive measurements
>return to weight x over time period u, take extensive measurements
>introduce pioglitazone dose
>change weight by y in over time period t, take extensive measurements
>compare measurements and note changes between hrt plus weight change (incl. y = 0 if chosen) alone vs hrt plus weight change plus pioglitazone

There are obviously more ways that this could be improved in good ways, but this is accessible to everyone and I wouldn't call someone's data shit for not doing more.

Some basic reading on pio suggests it has a potentially very not good cardiac damage axis particularly in endocrine-female patients (aka, anyone on MtF HRT too). The leg swelling people keep mentioning is fluid buildup from the first stage of congestive heart failure, which pio is known to initiate and potentially exacerbate in some cases.

It is by far the most dangerous DIY thing suggested so far as far as I've seen. It's also entirely possible that the feminization/fillout gains are actually partly influenced by the fluid retention described above, which means they'll dissipate once pio is stopped, or if it potentially kills you. I think I'm gonna skip this one.

>>29609206
it probably will, weight gain is a common side effect from pioglitazone, because it helps stimulate hyperplastic growth of adiposities (new fat cells) rather then hypertrophic (bigger fat cells) which often time causes inflammation and a variety of endocrine disorders.
at that early on HRT, you should just take a mild dose because its unknown if it stunts mammary gland maturation, so 15mg or less until 2 years HRT would be advised. make sure you're getting steady cardio and healthy fats if you're trying to gain some weight too and you should be fine.

I've stsrted to become bothered by this one type of post that crops up in almost every thread here every day.

People often call this poster "gincel" and it says the same several things:

>Trans women are homophobic gay men in denial
>trans women should be forced off HRT
>it's okay to be a feminine male
>you don't need to castrate yourself to be a feminine male

And some other variations of the above. It's very tiresome and monotonous and crops up in totally unrelated threads. Are the Jannies even trying to do anything?

>its not a choice that is made based on bigotry but a pure sexual visual sorting algorithm.
>We all know what femininity looks like and we cant use ideology to compel us to think otherwise
Interesting. I wouldn't say it's based on bigotry either, but a lot of people are on the side of completely abolishing gender, which would mean that anyone that identifies as a woman would be seen as a woman.
Obviously, that is a very extreme case, even for me, and I consider myself to be pretty progressive, but I am at the point where I can see a non-passing transwoman (one who is at least trying, you know) and my mind recognizes her a woman without much thought. It's pretty easy for me to do that nowadays even without trying.

Now, how far do I personally want to take this? Do I want my mind to recognize literally any gigahon as a woman? Hmm, no, probably not. Even though in theory we would all be happier if it was that easy, it sounds like absolute chaos and my mind can't imagine how such a society would work.

>its just fake and we shouldnt want to live in a hugbox world anyway.
I wouldn't call it fake if it ends up becoming reality. I still don't like it personally, though. If it happens, it would mean beauty standards would be on the absolute rock bottom and, again, that sounds too chaotic for me and I can't imagine it.

posts.sub: This can be the moment we turn it around. You decide.
posts.com:
Sturgeon is resigning - There's no independent Scotland coming for us to flee to. Sandyford GIC is closing - There is now no official route for trans kids in the UK nationwide to be prescribed puberty blockers or HRT. As far as we know, Inglefield is still not allowed to operate due to misconduct - There is now no reputable FFS surgeon in the UK. As you know already, Labour aren't coming to our aid. Neither are the big American activists who only care about trans people in their own country. So this is where we are right now, in the eternal purgatory that is Hell Island. So what do we do about it? If we do nothing we might as well commit mass ritual suicide rather than linger in this half-life for a few decades more. I don't think we've explored all our options.

Pic related is a map of all the vigils announced for Brianna Ghey so far. Just by going through the related tweets on the subject we've messaged DIY info privately to at least a dozen parents on the subject and a few more on Instagram too, and given the direness of the situation, many of them have already come back thanking us and saying it's an option for them now things are as bad as they are. Many local families with trans kids are going to be turning up to these vigils; the Bristol one last night had about 700 people in attendance. If one person from here went to each of these vigils to give out DIY info and to tell the trans people there to discreetly pass the info along to others they know in need, hundreds of trans lives could be transformed for the better overnight.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>29625534
(cont.)
Take the case of Alice Litman, a trans woman who was in the news recently after she killed herself due to the long waiting lists for HRT in this country. A trans life ended for want of the simple piece of information that you can buy HRT online at any time. A life that will never return or continue in any circumstance, not just because of transphobic institutions but because we failed her. It is unconscionable that trans people just like you are literally dying only because what should be entry-level community knowledge hasn't been networked outwards to the people all across the country who don't know it exists. Forming an active and effective resistance is now the only way, as others living under oppressive regimes have done in the past, to fight for our survival in a way that matters. And what's more, it's an option we haven't bothered putting to the test until today.

This can change overnight if you want it to. Like a drug addict for whom the OD of a friend is the final straw, we can put the path of least resistance, the current way of doing things, of limpid placard protests and corporate 'visibility' and 'representation' while watching things just get worse, behind us in one firm and deliberate movement if we simply decide to. No more illegible protest signs drawn on dark pieces of cardboard that immediately dissolve in the rain. No more standing outside in the cold for a few hours yelling nebulous chants like 'Trans rights now!' at an unresponsive NHS etc. building, deflating our righteous anger through a pressure release valve and patting ourselves on the back for a job well done before going home to the same miserable lives we had before.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>29625542
(cont.)
No more appealing to the people punching us in the face for mercy when they have zero incentive to stop. You decide whether today you start compiling materials to help trans people in your local area become a part of a wider movement, a society within the oppressive society, a liquid society thriving in the cracks in the system the powerful have too much hubris to recognise exist. We must rush in like a powerful tide and make our home there, so that as our numbers grow and our organisation cements, we may blow apart the whole rotten island in our sheer numbers once and for all - but only if we, and that means you, take active care of one another right now and make up for lost time organising our community materially like we should have been doing for the past decade already.

Much has been made over the past 24 hours of the lack of intersectionality in the LGBT movement in the west, specifically the lack of recognition of black trans people, and yeah, I get it, the "Think about us not the girl who just got murdered in your country" posts are annoying but I think what most USA TPoC have failed to articulate is the material ways in which the dominance of white, middle-class, liberal trans/queers over our movement has hurt *all* trans people here, white trans people as well. To be precise, it's the complacency of assuming that the electoral politics and liberal power structures that served our benefit (for some of us; the most vocal and media-visible, at least) when we were read as cis by society would continue to function to our benefit when campaigning as sensible, reasonable, neutral trans people just trying to live our lives etc. etc. due to a failure to take on board the experiences of those who know the truth of our "liberal" society: The brutal, centuries-old imperial power structure that lies behind the facade, and the fact that it exists not in a state of *peace*time as we commonly assume, no, but one of *order*.

It's not my place to harangue you on racial politics but it is time to face up to the fact that what we have been doing to date is not working. So, in material reality, it's very simple. We have a choice: Keep doing what you've been doing before you read this, and condemn yourself to watching a better life you could have had be overwritten with disappointment and misery by people you'll never meet. Or you can renounce this inevitablism, the British way of "That's just how the world is" and "Better things aren't possible" and start taking active steps to remedy our situation. It starts with transforming young British trans lives with DIY HRT information.

It can progress to country-wide accessible-cost martial arts classes for self-defence (womens' self-defence courses are too gimmicky and commercialised), an organised push to get UK trans surgery fundraisers into the eyeballs of Americans who are more likely to donate (US trans fundraisers often make their goals just fine, due to there already being an established culture of fundraising for general healthcare & therefore a bigger more receptive audience), and better IRL community throughout the provinces. But it takes each of you realising you are not the exception to the rule who gets to sit back and play observer to others doing this stuff for real.

"Spit on your own and you can't do anything. But if we all spit together we can drown the bastards." - RMT Union General Secretary, Bob Crow.

>>29629815
literally every single person who is polyamorous is mentally ill

you ever notice how every polyamorous relationship is super dramatic? that's because in every relationship, there is going to be (at some point) friction/drama between the partners. one feels unappreciated, one unintentionally said something to hurt the other, etc. with polyamorous relationships, every person has some kind of drama with every other partner they are involved.

so if 2 people have the normal amount of drama in a relationship, 3 people have 3x the drama, 4 people have 6x the drama, 5 people have 10x the drama, 6 people have 15x the drama, and so on.

you can work through the relationship issues, but even the normal amount of issues can be hard enough, nevermind when you're dealing with 10 times that.

for those familiar with graph theory or combinatorics, the amount of drama is the number of edges in a complete graph with n edges, where n is the number of people in the polycule.

There is a genetic limit to what hormones alone can do, but there is no one-size-fits-all HRT regimen that will get everyone to that point. Getting periodic blood hormone panels and adjusting your meds accordingly is vital to actually reaching your genetic feminization potential. Your transition can and will stall out well before you get there, if your body isn’t getting the right hormonal signaling.
